sp.p: (pointing to his mother.) Ah! ſir, my mama is ſo poor!

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: (chucking him under the chin.) Good little ſoul! Have you given up then the only object of your wiſhes, in order to relieve your mother? It would be very hard, indeed, that you ſhould loſe a watch for doing ſo. (He takes out his own) There! if I had but this ſingle watch, I would give it to you, to reward your affection.

sp.speaker: The Page,
sp.p: (taking it joyfully.) Ah! ſir. But does it go!

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Never fear; it goes very well. (The Page runs to his mother, to ſhew her the watch.)

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Come, my little friend, put up your watch. And ſince you have made ſo good uſe of the little that I gave you, (gives him his purſe,) here, take this. There are a hundred guineas inſtead of the firſt twelve.

sp.speaker: The Page
sp.p: (looking at him with aſtoniſhment.) Sir?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Do you heſitate? Here, take them.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: What, the purſe, ſir, and all that is — (Going to return it.) Indeed it is too much.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Yes, for yourſelf. But I give it to you, that you may diſpoſe of it. And who do you think wants it moſt?

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Who wants it? (Looks at the Prince and his mother by turns.) There mama, take it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen,
sp.p: (coming forward towards the Prince.) Your highneſs—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Pray, no acknowledgements, madam. You will find that it is very little, and I fear it may be of more harm to you than advantage. But (pointing to the Page) I need not tell you that this child is too weak and too little for my ſervice. At his age, children are hardly able to do much for others. In ſhort, I hope you will have no objection to take him back again. You are ſilent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: Your highneſs will excuſe—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: I own, ſir, I am wrong to bluſh for a poverty which I did not bring upon myſelf, and I may without diſgrace ingenuouſly confeſs it to my ſovereign. (Coming nearer, and looking ſtedfaſtly at him.) Yes, fir; my circumſtances are too narrow to maintain and bring up my ſon. I have long looked forward to the future with an anxious eye; and now my fears are real. I ſhall be the victim of grief. Ah! if I muſt carry back with me into the ſorrowful retreat of miſery this child that your highneſs returns to me, who is the only object of all my concern; this child who is too young as yet— (endeavouring to contain her tears) to—feel the loſs of a father— Ah! pardon a mother's weakneſs.

sp.speaker: The Page,
sp.p: (taking the Prince's hand,) ſorrowfully. Mama is crying. ſir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Well! ſuppoſing that you were to live with your mother?

sp.speaker: The Page,
sp.p: (with a look of entreaty.) Your highneſs won't ſend me home?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: No? Do you think not? This conſidence, my little friend, pleaſes me. Madam, he may ſtay. And yet it would be a pity if his morals, his innocence—But, no. There is nothing to fear as yet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen,
sp.p: (looking at him attentively.) His innocence did your highneſs ſay?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: There is no fear, madam. You would imagine perhaps that I wiſh to draw back my word. But don't be uneaſy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen,
sp.p: (fearfully.) Yet, might I take the liberty, without breaking through the reſpect that I owe your highneſs, to requeſt you to explain yourſelf—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Madam, what I meant was this. I have for ſome time paſt been extremely diſſatisfied with my pages. Their company and example might perhaps—Yet after all it is but a perhaps, and one may try—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen,
sp.p: (eagerly ſeizing her ſon's hand.) No, ſir.

sp.speaker: The Prince,
sp.p: (affecting diſpleaſure.) No? As you pleaſe, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: My ſon's innocence is too dear to me. I ſhudder at the dangers to which I was going to expoſe him.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: But conſider—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: I conſider nothing: I ſee my ſon in the midſt of the flames; and if I can but ſave him, no matter, though he ſhould be naked.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: But without fortune, without education, madam, what will become of him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: Whatever it ſhall pleaſe heaven. I ſubmit to the divine will. If he cannot ſupport his birth, let him go labour in the fields; let him die in poverty, but retain his innocence.

sp.speaker: The Prince
sp.p: (in his natural manner.) This is thinking nobly. Yes, madam, I ſee, you deſerve every thing that I can poſſibly do for you. (Coming nearer to her and ſpeaking with earneſtneſs.) In what can I be of aſſiſtance to you? Tell me how I can ſerve you. Only ſpeak, you ſee a friend before you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen,
sp.p: (with emotion.) Ah! ſir—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Tell me firſt of all what is your ſituation. How are you with regard to your eſtate?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: It will be abſolutely impoſſible, ſir, for me to ſave it.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Your debts then are pretty conſiderable? You are at law now, I am told. Do not they give you any hopes?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: None, ſir. One cauſe, concerning a ſmall inheritance, ſhould have been decided long ago in my favour. My title is indiſputable. But intereſt and money are againſt it. Neceſſity brought me hither to town, in order to endeavour a compromiſe, but I could not ſucceed.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: So much the better. You ſhall have juſtice now, without making any ſacrifice, I give you my word of honour; and accept moreover a penſion of a hundred a year. I hope that it will put you above every neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen,
sp.p: (throwing herſelf at his feet.) Oh! ſir, ſo much goodneſs! how ſhall I—

sp.speaker: The Prince,
sp.p: (raiſing her.) What are you doing, madam? Riſe, I requeſt you. I only diſcharge what I owe to the memory of a man whoſe widow you are. I do for you no more than I would do for any one whoſe virtue I eſteemed. Tell me, would you ſtill heſitate to take back your child?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: Sir, could I ſo forget—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: And you, my little friend, would you like to go back with your mother?

sp.speaker: The Page,
sp.p: (playing with his watch.) With my mother? Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: And yet now I know that you love me, would not you like as well to ſtay with me?

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Yes, very well, ſir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Now, if that be ſo, were I to give you back to your mother, it would be ſending you away from me, and you have aſked me ſo earneſtly to keep you here. Beſides, your mother has thrown you into my arms. I muſt therefore take another way to ſettle matters. Stop here, madam, I ſhall be with you in a moment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen,
sp.p: (throwing herſelf into an arm chair.) O bleſſed day! O unexpected happineſs!

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Well, mama; well, are you glad?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen,
sp.p: (drawing him to her affectionately.) O my ſon, my dear ſon!

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: But you do not rejoice. You ought to be merrier, mama.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: Even my happineſs makes me bluſh. It reproaches me for the little truſt that I had in Providence, and for the ſorrow that I felt when you came into the world. It was but a moment after I had heard of the loſs of your father. I looked at you with pity, and lamented that you ever ſaw the light. (She takes him in her arms and kiſſes him.) Yet it was you that was to relieve your unfortunate mother! your young hands were to dry up her tears! O heaven! what can I now deſire more? Nothing, nothing, but to be ſure of your brother's lot, and then my happineſs would be complete.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: My brother's? Why, mama, what of him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: If the prince knew what he has done—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: And if he did, there would be nothing of it. You ſaw how good and how generous he is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: To us, my dear, who are not guilty of any crime.

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Beſides, he promiſed me that he would not tell, and that the colonel ſhould know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen,
sp.p: (frightened) What! he promiſed you!

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Yes, indeed: ſo you need not be afraid.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: I am thunder-ſtruck. You have told him then?

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Nay, hardly any thing. Only all that I knew. And then he aſked me concerning my brother's behaviour, and ſo I could not tell a fib. You know you bid me never to do ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: But, my dear child—

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Why, mama, are you uneaſy?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: Uneaſy? O heavens! can you aſk? Oh! if the prince ſhould enquire farther, if he ſhould be informed—You may ruin your mother and your brother! you may plunge us all into the deepeſt miſery.

sp.speaker: The Page,
sp.p: (ready to cry.) The deepeſt miſery?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: Somebody comes— (She kiſſes and encourages him.) Say not a word. Dry up your tears. They will only, perhaps, make the matter worſe. Do not be uneaſy.

div.head: SCENE XIII.
div.stage: Mrs. Dorffen, the Page, the Prince followed by Captain Derenhoff, and Enſign Dorffen.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Come in, gentlemen. (To the Enſign.) You are enſign Dorffen, then? the ſon of that brave Major?

sp.speaker: Enſign Dorffen,
sp.p: (bowing very low.) Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: That is a great recommendation with me. Your father was a man of honour and a brave officer. I have no doubt but his example rouſes your emulation, and that you ſtrive to make yourſelf worthy of him.

sp.speaker: Enſign Dorffen.
sp.p: Sir, I only do my duty.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: That is doing every thing. The braveſt man can do no more. There, ſir, is your mother: her virtues, and the hopes that may be formed of this amiable child, have given me the moſt favourable idea of your family; and therefore I wiſhed to ſee you all aſſembled here.

sp.speaker: Enſign Dorffen,
sp.p: (ſtill bowing.) Your highneſs does me particular honour!

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: No more, certainly, than you deſerve.

sp.speaker: Enſign Dorffen,
sp.p: Your highneſs judges favourably of me.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Really, ſir, I only want to be confirmed in the opinion that I am tempted to form of you at preſent, in order to make your fortune: and yet that air of freedom and confidence that becomes you ſo well—

sp.speaker: Enſign Dorffen.
sp.p: Ah! ſir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Denotes (permit me to ſay) a heart either very noble, or very corrupt. The ſon of ſuch parents cannot be ſuſpected. Certainly not. Therefore, ſir, what can we do to ſerve you? A ſtep higher would not advance you much in rank. What think you?

sp.speaker: Enſign Dorffen
sp.p: (rubbing his hands.) No, certainly ſir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Now, if we were to paſs over this ſtep? A Company! the rank of captain! It is the main object with you young gentlemen. But firſt— (turning ſhort round to Capt. Derenhoff) Sir, what is your opinion of your nephew?

sp.speaker: Capt. Derenhoff
sp.p: (ſomething confuſed.) Mine, ſir? My opinion?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: One would think it to be unfavourable.

sp.speaker: Capt. Derenhoff.
sp.p: No, ſir, rather much the contrary; I believe that he has courage, and will be a brave—

sp.speaker: The Prince
sp.p: (looking with ſatisfaction at enſign Dorffen.) Ay is that true?

sp.speaker: Capt. Derenhoff.
sp.p: Beſides, he has a promiſing figure.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: He is a fine lad, I confeſs. But his behaviour, his morals? I am aſhamed, indeed, to aſk you about ſuch trifles. In ſhort, what is his character?

sp.speaker: Capt. Derenhoff
sp.p: (ſmiling.) Oh! a little too airy, ſometimes petulant. After all, ſir, you know, that does not miſbecome a ſoldier.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: I know? Really that is ſomething new to me. I want now, madam, only your teſtimony. What will you ſay of your ſon?— (After a pauſe) Nothing?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: What ſhould I ſay of him?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: What you think. The truth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: But can I, ſir? If I had reaſon to praiſe him, would you wiſh me to do it in his preſence? or ſhould I ſpeak to his prejudice before him who can determine his fortune?

sp.speaker: The Prince,
sp.p: (ſmiling.) Excellent, madam. To the fondneſs of a mother you join the addreſs of a woman. I cannot but admire you. (In a ſerious tone.) Sir, every one has his way. I have mine, when I mean to advance an officer, I begin with putting him under arreſt. What do you think of it?

sp.speaker: Enſign Dorffen,
sp.p: (frightened.) Sir—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p:
Yes, that is my manner. Give up your ſword to the captain. An air of more modeſty would have excuſed all. But this confidence, this undaunted to • e—What can be expected from a perſon who with your conſcience is maſter of ſuch aſſurance? who ſhould be ſenſible that he has deſerved my diſpleaſure? who knows how unworthily he has treated the beſt of mothers? and who nevertheleſs—Sir, let him be confined for a month. I will have no explanation upon what is paſt, and that on your account, madam, and becauſe of the manner in which I came by my information; but particularly becauſe
circumſtances make me preſume that his fault is of a weighty nature— (With a ſevere and determined voice.) Captain, if hereafter any thing ſhould happen, I deſire to be informed of it immediately, you underſtand? immediately. I mean to advance this young man; and neither you (to the captain,) nor (in a gentler tone) you, madam, ſhall make me alter my plan—Never give him any thing, never the ſmalleſt trifle by way of preſent. His pay may ſerve him; and let him learn to contract his expences. (Making a ſign with his hand.) Go, ſir, to your confinement. (The two officers go out.)

div.head: SCENE XIV.
div.stage: The Prince, Mrs. Dorffen, the Page.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Well, madam, you ſeem dejected.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen,
sp.p: (reſpectfully.) Sir, I am a mother.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: But you are not one of thoſe weak mothers, who, to ſpare their children a ſlight mortification, chuſe not to correct them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: That would be a very falſe tenderneſs. No, ſir, I only fear that he may have loſt for ever his prince's favour.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Do not be uneaſy, madam. My deſign is barely to make him worthy of the favours that I mean to beſtow on him. His youth claims ſome indulgence, therefore I excuſe his levities and indiſcretion; but I ſhall not always do ſo. What in one perſon brings back the love of virtue along with repentance, will in another ſtrengthen his inclination to vice. Upon the whole, make yourſelf eaſy. The young gentleman will come to himſelf, and I ſhall proportion my favour to his improvement. (Turning to the page.) As to this child, do you know what my intentions are?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: Whatever they are, ſir, they will only aim to ſecure his happineſs. O, ſir! I have never let paſs a day without paying to your virtues the tribute of my homage, but I now ſee how far it fell below them.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p:
What would you ſay, madam? You do not know me. My object is to give the ſtate a worthy
member, and myſelf a faithful ſervant, and to raiſe up for my ſon a friend who may one day be ready to ſacrifice his life for him as his father has done for me.

div.head: SCENE XV.
div.stage: The Prince, Mrs. Dorffen, the Page, Attendant.

sp.speaker: Attendant.
sp.p: Pleaſe your highneſs, the Maſter of the Royal Academy.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Let him come in. I hope, madam, that you need only to be informed of my intentions to approve them.

div.head: SCENE XVI.
div.stage: The Prince, Mrs. Dorffen, the Page, the Maſter of the Academy.

sp.speaker: The Maſter,
sp.p: (bowing.) I am come according to your highneſs's orders.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Your ſervant, ſir, I am glad to ſee you. What do children of the firſt condition pay at the Royal Academy?

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: Of the firſt condition, ſir? That is a • parents agree.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: However, mention the terms.

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: Sixty pounds, ſir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Very well. This child I mean to ſend to you. And as I ſhall be inſtead of a father to him, I propoſe to do as much for him as the beſt gentlemen do for their children. But tell me, who has the care of attending to theſe young perſons? for that is the eſſential point.

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: The different maſters, ſir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Who are, I ſuppoſe, qualified for their employment. But I do not know them. It is on you alone, ſir, that I wiſh to depend. You have gained my confidence. Would you be ſo good as to take this child particularly under your own care?

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: Sir, it is my duty.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: I do not mean to make it a duty to you. Will it be agreeable?

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: Sir, my duty is always agreeable to me.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Very well. You may depend then on my gratitude. (To the Page, as he takes him by the hand.) Come hither, my man; do you ſee this gentleman? he is mild and good-natured; would you like to go and live with him?

sp.speaker: The Page,
sp.p: (after looking a moment at the maſter.) Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: But obſerve, you are to look upon this gentleman as your maſter, as your benefactor. You are to ſhew him the greateſt obedience, and the moſt dutiful reſpect; and if ever he has reaſon to complain of you—

sp.speaker: The Page.
sp.p: Oh! ſir, he never ſhall.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: You have ſeen that I can be as ſevere as I am gentle. So that at the ſmalleſt complaint—

sp.speaker: The Page,
sp.p: (bowing reſpectfully to the maſter.) I hope, ſir, you ſhall never have reaſon to complain of me.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: How do you like this child?

sp.speaker: The Maſter.
sp.p: It is enough, ſir, that I receive him from your hands; that will make him always dear to me as my own ſon.

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Well then, he may go with you. You have no objection, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: Heavens, ſir! objection?

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: Go then, my dear; and never quit the paths of virtue and honour. I have only to add, that you may make yourſelf eaſy; you ſhall never want. But why ſo dull?

sp.speaker: The Page,
sp.p: (taking the prince's hand.) I wiſh your highneſs all happineſs.

sp.speaker: The Prince,
sp.p: (tenderly.) And I you the ſame, my good little friend. God bleſs you, my dear. How grateful his heart is already! Now, ſir, you may take him: and you, madam, accompany this gentleman, and ſee where your ſon is to be.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen,
sp.p: (throwing herſelf at his feet.) Can I leave your highneſs without humbly—

sp.speaker: The Prince.
sp.p: What are you doing, madam? I do not like this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: Permit me to—

sp.speaker: The Prince,
sp.p: (raiſing her.) By no means. Riſe, madam. I cannot ſuffer that in any body.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Dorffen.
sp.p: Well, I obey your highneſs, and take my leave— (Lifting up her hands.) I will bend then before my Maker, and pray him to protect for ever ſo generous a prince.

sp.speaker: The Prince,
sp.p: (with condeſcenſion, accompanying her a few ſteps.) Farewel, madam, I wiſh you happy.
